answers.answer: I forgot to mention my most bizarre symptom. I like to do things sitting on the floor, strange I know, but recently, when I'm sitting on the floor, I get the strangest sensations in my legs. First, they get really hot. I continue sitting because I really don't think anything of it, but then I start feeling like all the nerve endings in me legs are having a party. It's hard to explain the sensation, except that I feel like my legs are full of boiling water-- not because they're hot, but because it feels like everything in my legs is bubbling. It's the most bizarre thing, but it's not really uncomfortable, just a little off-putting and distracting. I've also had dry, itchy skin all over my body, as well as rashes on the forearms. Thanks!

Your symptoms could be caused by a number of things. The thirst, vision problems, and headaches could be signs of diabetes.  The pain in your legs could be lupus.  Other things you mention sound like hypothyroidism.  Blood work would rule out a lot of diagnosis...especially blood sugar, ANA, TSH and potassium levels.  If your rheumatologist won't order the tests, your GP should be able to.  Best wishes.

So I forgot more things. My hands and feet are sweaty and cold. I sometimes get this really queer feeling on the pinky side of my right hand where if I rub it, not touch it, it gets really hypersensitive. It happens other places too, but mostly on the side of my right hand. I also crave strange foods like lentils and tomato sauce. My lips are always always chapped, and no amount of medicated lip balm will help remedy that. My hands and feet swell up a lot too.
I would strongly recommend asking your physician to test you for Sjogren's Syndrome:http://www.ninds.nih.gov/disorders/sjogrens/sjogrens.htm

I was also thinking Sjogren's Syndrome, even before I saw the other commets. You do need to get autoimmune tests done. ANA, Sed-rate, SS-A and SS-B antibodies. There is actually a long list, but the web page I need is not working right now. I will post again later if I can access the list though. An Opthamologist can diagnose Sjogren's, or find why you're having problems with your eyes. You should not neglect to get tested for Diabetes though. That was also a good suggestion.
But isn't Sjrogen's mostly people over like 35? Because I'm not even 20.
Usually it does affect middle aged people, but it can also affect younger people, including teenagers.
But wouldn't that mean that I wouldn't be sweating, because my immune system would be eating my sweat glands? Because my hands and feet sweat way more than can possible be normal.
If you are hypoglycemic the peanut butter would help that since it's a slow burning protein.  I.E., it stays in your system longer and keeps you from having low blood sugar.  Just a thought.

I honestly can't answer your question, but you may be right. One thing is obvious, you need a complete work-up by your physician and I agree with lhowell about getting a glucose level (blood sugar), ANA, TSH. But I also believe you should get a CBC/DIFF, tests to rule out Sjogren's, RF and screening for hepatitis and to rule lyme disease.
I was reading a bunch of threads, and just out of curiosity, just how is it that you know everything about everything?
I wish I knew everything about everything, then I would have more answers for you ! ;^)
So one of the more entertaining symptoms that I have is that the only thing that will make me feel better is peanut butter. Anyone know why?
My rheumatologist also confirmed that I don't have any joint swelling, which is caused by arthritis, so I'm completely stumped.

Have you had your vitamin D blood levels tested?Most of the symptoms you describe can be caused by vitamin D deficiency or could in turn lead towards a vitamin D deficiency.  Extreme low vitamin D can lead to neurological problems, problems with blood sugar, joint, muscle and bone pain, hormone imbalances, calcium deficiencies, etc.Recent studies are showing that most people are below minimal levels of vitamin D and that the minimal levels are probably too low to begin with.  It's just a blood test to check your current levels but it could be revealing even if only a part of the overall problem.
Check for Chronic kidney failure disease.  I have similar pains and have yet to get this checked.

question: I've had joint pain for a few years, but never anything really bad until a few months ago when my joints starting squeaking and cracking when I moved. Then, recently, I've been having strange pains in the middle of my second-to-last rib on my right side when I life my right arm. I've also been thirsty all the time, and I have headaches. I've been urinating all the time, and it's neon yellow. My eyes are incessantly dry, and when I stand up after laying or sitting for along time my vision goes all sorts of colours and I have to sit back down, at which point that goes away and I'm fine. Sometimes when I wake up in the morning I can't move becuase my body is so tired. I've been to a rheumatologist, and she told me that it was nothing to worry about, but I definitely am worrying.
title: Joint pain plus new symptoms
